[[1]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-1) [[2]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-2) This page refers to Astragalus membranaceus, a popular herb used in [traditional Chinese [[4]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-4) Astragalus membranaceus can be used alone, but it is also paired with another herb called Angelicae sinensis in Danggui Buxue Tang, a Chinese bioactive compounds, including polysaccharides, [flavonoids](/foods/flavonoids/), and saponins. One of its major bioactive molecules is called astragaloside IV. [[6]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-6) [[7]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-7), and another of its bioactive extracts has been patented under the name TA-65 (telomerase activator 65). [[8]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-8) There are widespread claims about the beneficial effects of Astragalus membranaceus and its extracts (e.g., astragaloside IV, TA-65, etc.) on several conditions. These include chronic heart failure, [[9]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-9) [[10]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-10) [[22]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-22) [[23]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-23) [[24]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-24) [[25]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-25) However, the quality of evidence for these effects in humans is generally low because of variable findings between studies, poor methodological quality, unclear methodological details, widespread lack of blinding, use of intravenous rather than oral administration, and [publication bias](https://catalogofbias.org/biases/publication-bias/) in favor of predominantly positive the evidence supporting the benefits of astragaloside IV is derived from animal and cell culture experiments, [[26]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-26) [[15]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-15) [[16]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-16) [[27]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-27) [[21]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-21) [[28]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-28) while clinical studies showing the therapeutic benefit of TA-65 are authored by the group that patented the compound. [[8]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-8) [[11]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-11) Consequently, high-quality randomized controlled clinical trials by independent researchers are urgently needed to confirm these therapeutic claims. For example, systematic reviews conclude that evidence in this field is generally of low unclear which species (e.g., Astragalus membranaceus) or part (entire plant, roots, flowers, etc.) of an Astragalus plant is used, or which type of extract is administered (i.e., a total or purified extract). Additionally, astragalus extracts are often combined with other compounds or drugs so their direct effects cannot always be determined. These limitations reduce the certainty of the claimed benefits. Pharmacological research indicates that Astragalus membranaceus [[3]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-3) and immunological systems, as well as increase telomerase activity, which prolongs the lifespan of cells. This may explain the potential role of astragalus in the treatment of chronic disease. However, most pharmacological evidence is derived from cell culture (i.e., in vitro) and animal experiments. [[26]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-26) [[15]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-15) [[16]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-16) [[27]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-27) [[21]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-21) [[28]](/supplements/astragalus/#ref-28) Further clinical pharmacology research is needed to fully understand the potential mechanism(s) of action in humans. - Astragalus - huangqi - (A Component Of) Danggui Buxue Tang (DBT) - Membranous Milk-vetch Root - Astragalus Sinensis are highly synergistic, meaning they are more powerful when taken together. This combination is traditionally called Dang-gui buxue tang. The starting point for the preparation of Dang-gui buxue tang in traditional Chinese medicine is 30g membranaceus root paired with 6g of Angelicae sinensis. This is a 5:1 ratio, which is ideal for extracting the bioactive ingredients of the plants. Astragalus membranaceus can also be supplemented via a root extract. Due to potential differences in the quality/efficiency of the extraction process among different commercial manufacturers, product label recommendations for dosage should be followed and you should consult with your pharmacist or personal physician before taking. The main bioactive compound in Astragalus membranaceus is astragaloside IV, which can be supplemented by itself. The standard dose for astragaloside IV is 5-10mg.
